subject: pickle_async_update should create tmp_dir
commit_message:
pickle_async_update should create tmp_dir

While creating a probe test for the expirer daemon, I found
the following error scenario:

1. Introduce a new object server. Initially it doesn't have a tmp_dir.
2. Have the object-replicator replicate some objects, one of them
    with an expiration (X-Delete-At).
3. Send a DELETE request for the expired object.

While beginning to process the DELETE request, the fresh
object server still doesn't have a tmp_dir created.
Since the object has an old expiration value, the object server
will first call "delete_at_update", before creating a tombstone.
delete_at_update then must create an async_pending,
which will lead to an IO error, since tmp_dir doesn't exist.

As said, I have witnessed this in practice in the probe test I wrote
at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/326903/.

This patch changes pickle_async_update behavior to create
tmp_dir, in case it doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I88b0e5f75a2a28d6880694ff327ac2763c816d24

subject: Skip INVALID and UNASSIGNED ofport in vlan restore
commit_message:
Skip INVALID and UNASSIGNED ofport in vlan restore

get_vif_ports returns ports with INVALID and UNASSIGNED
ofports and get_vif_port_set does not. The main scan_ports
loop uses the latter so any INVALID ofports (i.e. ofport == -1)
will be treated as removed and have their local VLANs reclaimed.
So an INVALID ofport could have the same local VLAN as a new
port that was added after it had been reclaimed.

This was causing an error in the _restore_local_vlan_map function
since it was using get_vif_ports which would cause it to process
INVALID ports as well so it could get two network UUIDs using the
same VLAN.

This fixes it by skipping INVALID and UNASSIGNED ofports in the
vlan restoration so it matches the behavior of scan_ports
(which is responsible for deciding which ports are added/removed
for VLAN allocation).

Closes-Bug: #1526974
Change-Id: I9d722fa4fabd467ded44d9cd291a3fa4d1af90f6

subject: Convergence: Fix concurrent update resource delete
commit_message:
Convergence: Fix concurrent update resource delete

In convergence, wherein concurrent updates are possible, if a resource
is deleted (by previous traversal) after dependency graph is created
for new traversal, the resource remains in graph but wouldn't be
available in DB for processing.
It is prerequisite to have resources in DB before any action can be
taken on them.

Hence during convergence resource delete action, the resource entry
from DB is not deleted i.e soft deleted, so that the latest/new update
can find the entry.
All of these soft deleted resources will be deleted when the stack has
completed its operation.

Closes-Bug: #1528560
Change-Id: I0b36ce098022560d7fe01623ce7b66d1d5b38d55

subject: Remove floatingip addresses from router device
commit_message:
Remove floatingip addresses from router device

Current code will try to add floating IP address to external gateway
device in centralized router namespace. It's a convenient way to do
proxy arp for centralized router. But for DVR router, specially the
DVR local router, it inherits the same way to configure floating IP
address, so it will cause issue in [1]. Traffic sent to a floating
IP which happens to map to a fixed ip on the same network should go
through the routers default SNAT. In DVR, this means routing the traffic
through the centralized SNAT part of the router. The problem is that
since the IP address is configured on the router's device, it thinks
it owns the address and will not route it through.

The solution is fixing previous SNAT iptable rules and removing
floating IP addresses from router_2_fip device in DVR local router
namespace. The needed-by patch[2] will work on that.

But that will mean the DVR router would handle floating IPs inconsistently
with non-DVR routers. Since the only reason to add the address to the
router's interface is for proxy arp, we can instead configure arp proxy
in all cases to be consistent.

[1] a VM ping another VM on the same host with the later one's
floating IP address, but get replied by the later one's fixed
IP address. https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1462154
[2] remove floating IP address from DVR router device

The existing code that exists for the l3 scheduler is extremely raceful
since multiple workers (initiated from both RPC and API) can call this
code. One option to deal with these races is sending numerous patches
that check these races and if found - fix them. The other option is
using a DLM (Distributed Locking Mechanism).

Thankfully, OpenStack already has a DLM library called tooz, and this
patch introduces it to Neutron.

This patch exists mainly to show that "it can be done" and that it's
quite easy. There are multiple details to look into here, including:
1. Which backend do we want? (I chose redis because ceilometer uses it
   but a few more are available, including etcd, consul, ZooKeeper...)
   Also, need to add devstack support for whichever one we use
2. Do we want to use a ring-based synchronization method? A centralized
   managing entity? A consensus-based algorithm? If so, how many to
   establish a consensus?
3. How often do we want to update that we're up? (I used a hard-coded
   10 but we probably want it to be configurable)

[l2pop] fix agents failing to create flood flows

When multiple api and rpc workers enabled for neutron-server,
sometimes ovs agents fail to create/remove flood flows to other ovs
agents(as l2pop driver is failing to identify first/last port).
Please see bug report for complete description.

Instead of agent depending on l2pop driver to notify when to create
or delete flood flows to other agents, let agent decide this on their
own. With this change ovs agent will maintain list of ports on "other
agent" for "each network", like below,
lvm.tun_ofports={<agent1>: [<port1_id>, <port20_id>, ..],
                 <agent2>: [<port12_id>, <port4_id>, ..]}

For first port on the list, it creates flood flow to that agent.

l2pop driver has to notify "only current port fdb" to all agents(only
fanout and no cast notification).In this new appraoch, new field 'port'
added to fdb_entries,because l2pop will always notify about a single
port and can avoid duplicate entries in port's fdb.

A new RPC added for agent to get existing network ports on remote agents
from l2pop driver, and create above list and flood entries to other agents
when first port on network(new lvm) on this local agent created(
same happens on agent restarts).

To maintain backword compatility with agents from previous releases,
l2pop driver still notifies about network ports to agent and also
all fdb fields retained.Once this obsolete code is removed, l2pop driver
will be simpler like in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/302325/

subject: Allow 'openstack baremetal configure boot' to guess the root device
commit_message:
Allow 'openstack baremetal configure boot' to guess the root device

This change simplifies using Ironic root device hints for people who only need
to change the default strategy of selecting the default device.
E.g. we have a use case for selecting the first device instead of the smallest,
so that the root device does not change after upgrade Kilo -> Liberty.

Note that this feature does not replace per-node device hints, rather
complement them with a more global and easy to use setting.

This change introduces 3 new arguments to the command:
--root-device states how to find a root devices for a node.
  If this argument is provided, the client will try to detect the root device
  based on the stored introspection data. Possible values:
  * smallest (the same thing as IPA does by default - the smallest device)
  * largest (the opposite thing - pick the largest device)
  * otherwise it's treated as a comma-separated list of possible device names,
    e.g. sda,vda,hda rouchly matches the logic the Kilo ramdisk used.
  The resulting device WWN or serial (whatever is available) is then recorded
  in the root device hints (/properties/root_device) for a node.
--root-device-minimum-size minimum size of the considered devices
  The default value of 4 GiB matches what IPA does.
--overwrite-root-device-hints allows overwriting root device hints set
  previously. It's disabled by default to allow more precise control over the
  root device for some subset of nodes.

Note that for these arguments to work, this command should be run after
introspection. A separate documentation change will be posted for that.

Closes-Bug: #1588433

subject: Dump and restore galera db during major upgrades
commit_message:
Dump and restore galera db during major upgrades

When the overcloud is upgraded we do a yum update of the packages.
This step might introduce a newer galera version. In such a situation
we need to dump the db and restore it. The high-level workflow should
be the following:
1) During the main upgrade step, before shutting down the cluster
   we need to dump the db
2) We upgrade the packages
3) We briefly start mysql on a single node while making sure that
   /root/.my.cnf is briefly moved out of the way (because it contains
   a password) and import the data. After the import we shutdown this
   mysql instance
4) We let the cluster start up normally

The above steps will take place in the following scenarios.
Given a locally installed mariadb version X.Y.Z and release R,
we will dump and restore the DB under the following conditions:
A) MySqlMajorUpgrade template parameter is set to 'auto' and
   the upgraded package differs in X, Y *or* Z. We basically don't
   dump automatically if the release field changes.

B) MySqlMajorUpgrade template parameter is set to 'yes'

When MySqlMajorUpgrade is set to 'no', no dumping will be performed.
Note that this will give a non functional upgrade if a major mariadb
upgrade is taking place.

Partial-Bug: #1587449
